doc_id=1197 igt_id=igt1197-106 2397 2401 M+CN L+LN L+AL G+CN M+AC
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=2397 tag=M+CN:       (1)      a.   expletive pro

doc_id=1401 igt_id=igt1401-5 929 941 L+LN B G M M M M M B B M B T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=929 tag=L+LN:  (3)     a. Mér er illt í höf i. (MI)
line=930 tag=B:
line=931 tag=G:              me(D) is painful in head
line=932 tag=M:  7 Compare irregular case marking in Faroese: mær vantar eitt me(D) lack something `I
line=933 tag=M:  am lacking something.' Whereas Icelandic uses accusative case for the subject in its
line=934 tag=M:  comparable phrase mig vantar... , Faroese uses dative. This is one example of many
line=935 tag=M:  throughout the Germanic languages that shows that Icelandic is neither alone nor unique in
line=936 tag=M:  some of its use of case marking.
line=937 tag=B:
line=938 tag=B:
line=939 tag=M:                                                 9
line=940 tag=B:
line=941 tag=T:              `I have a headache.'

language: Icelandic (isl)
line=2245 tag=L-T:  (33)   V. baka `to bake'

doc_id=1401 igt_id=igt1401-70 2247 2268 L B B B M M M M M M B B B B G+CR G+CR B M+SY B M+SY B T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=2247 tag=L:         Dagmamman               baka i brau i .
line=2248 tag=B:
line=2249 tag=B:
line=2250 tag=B:
line=2251 tag=M:  17 YMJ claim that spreading accounts for some case marking in another Scandinavian
line=2252 tag=M:  language (Swedish). However, they first hold that spreading is not required in Icelandic
line=2253 tag=M:  since any extra NP is always assigned case in the lexicon. Later, they argue that in just the
line=2254 tag=M:  case of "quirky" verbs that take accusative subjects and accusative objects, spreading may
line=2255 tag=M:  be involved. Such verbs would presumably have to be either marked in the syntactic tier
line=2256 tag=M:  below the NP level or elsewhere in a different tier.
line=2257 tag=B:
line=2258 tag=B:
line=2259 tag=B:                                               32
line=2260 tag=B:
line=2261 tag=G+CR:                                   baked bread-the(A)18
line=2262 tag=G+CR:          day-mommy-the(N)
line=2263 tag=B:
line=2264 tag=M+SY:          NP                                NP
line=2265 tag=B:
line=2266 tag=M+SY:          N                                  A
line=2267 tag=B:
line=2268 tag=T:          `The day-mommy baked the bread.'

doc_id=3626 igt_id=igt3626-99 4339 4352 L+LN B B B M M M M M B M B G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=4339 tag=L+LN:          (17)     ... að      það        hafi rignt í gær.                                         (Icelandic)
line=4340 tag=B:
line=4341 tag=B:
line=4342 tag=B:
line=4343 tag=M:  104
line=4344 tag=M:     Vikner (1995, p. 48/74) points out that we do not find V2 (to be more precise, non-subject XPs preceding the
line=4345 tag=M:  finite verb) in embedded questions ­ on the other hand, embedded clauses can feature það (Vikner 1995, p.76).
line=4346 tag=M:  Sigurðsson (p.c.) assumes that embedded clauses just have V-to-T movement and he points out that certain types
line=4347 tag=M:  of embedded clauses do not even feature this V-movement.
line=4348 tag=B:
line=4349 tag=M:                                                         103
line=4350 tag=B:
line=4351 tag=G:                   ... that Expl105 has rained yesterday
line=4352 tag=T:                   "... that it rained yesterday."

line=526 tag=G+DB:            Choirs-the.ACC lacks money.ACC for trip-the.GEN                                                assertions about what is needed in the ideal state, whereas vanta makes an assertion about
line=527 tag=T+DB:            'The choirs lack money for the trip'                                                           what we are short of in the ideal state.

doc_id=4019 igt_id=igt4019-6 206 210 L G L G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=206 tag=L:             b. ?Þessum mannii / *þennan manni heilsa ég ti                  oft
line=207 tag=G:                 this man (D) / *(A)                greet I                  often
line=208 tag=L:                     án þess að tala nokkuð við e.
line=209 tag=G:                     without talk anything to
line=210 tag=T:                `This man, I often greet without talking to.'

doc_id=4019 igt_id=igt4019-7 212 214 L G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=212 tag=L:        (4) a. Ég sé þennan mann oft           án þess að hjálpa honum nokkurn tíma.
line=213 tag=G:               I see this man (A) often without             help him (D) any   time
line=214 tag=T:               `I often see this man without ever helping him.'

doc_id=4019 igt_id=igt4019-8 216 227 L B M M M B M B G L G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=216 tag=L:             b. ?Þennan manni / *þessum mannii sé ég ti               oft
line=217 tag=B:
line=218 tag=M:    3
line=219 tag=M:       In these and subsequent examples, (A) stands for accusative case, (D) stands for dative case, (G) stands
line=220 tag=M:  for genitive case and (N) stands for nominative case.
line=221 tag=B:
line=222 tag=M:                                       Eiríkur Rögnvaldsson
line=223 tag=B:
line=224 tag=G:              this man (A) / *(D)                see I         often
line=225 tag=L:                  án þess að hjálpa e nokkurn tíma.
line=226 tag=G:                  without help          anytime
line=227 tag=T:             `This man, I often see without ever helping him.'

line=254 tag=T:             `This man, Ann hates.'

doc_id=4019 igt_id=igt4019-22 396 411 L+SY B M M M M M M M M M B M B G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=396 tag=L+SY:           c. Jón / *Jóni           hafði farið snemma og              verið ekið heim.
line=397 tag=B:
line=398 tag=M:     6
line=399 tag=M:       Henceforth, I will use the term `CR-structures' descriptively to cover coordinate structures where each
line=400 tag=M:  conjunct has a finite verb and its complement, but there is only one overt subject. Thus, my use of this term
line=401 tag=M:  does not imply any commitment to the transformational analysis of such sentences.
line=402 tag=M:     7
line=403 tag=M:       Actually, the behavior of CR is also consistent with Franks' (1992, 7) principle: `All gaps in any ATB
line=404 tag=M:  construction must consistently pertain to either thematically must prominent or not most prominent
line=405 tag=M:  arguments.' This condition `holds regardless of the abstract Case or phrase structural position of the gaps in
line=406 tag=M:  question'.
line=407 tag=B:
line=408 tag=M:                                        Eiríkur Rögnvaldsson
line=409 tag=B:
line=410 tag=G:             John (N) / *(D) had left early          and been driven home
line=411 tag=T:             `John had left early and had been driven home.'

line=3889 tag=L+CR:  3.19       a.
line=3890 tag=G+CR:                  henom seems love           heracc
line=3891 tag=G+CR:                                       inf
line=3892 tag=M:       However, it seems that the nominative on external topics should be linked to the nominative as the
line=3893 tag=M:    38
line=3894 tag=B:
line=3895 tag=M:  `extrasentential' case, i.e., used to mark NPs not presentonany argument structure. We leave exploring this
line=3896 tag=M:  possibility for future research.
line=3897 tag=M:       A similar approach to case assignment can be found in Zlati 1997b, which came to our attention too
line=3898 tag=M:    39
line=3899 tag=B:
line=3900 tag=M:  late to be discussed here.
line=3901 tag=B:
line=3902 tag=M:  3.4. CASE IN HPSG                                                                                 59
line=3903 tag=B:
line=3904 tag=T:                 `He seems to love her.'

doc_id=4078 igt_id=igt4078-58 858 877 L G B B M M M M M M M M M B B B B M B T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=858 tag=L:  (48)   a       Henni leiddist strákarnir.
line=859 tag=G:                 her(D) bored(dft) the boys(N)
line=860 tag=B:
line=861 tag=B:
line=862 tag=M:    15
line=863 tag=M:      Other morphological case languages, e.g. Finnish and Russian, also offer evidence that
line=864 tag=M:  nominative case is sometimes licensed VP-internally.
line=865 tag=M:    16
line=866 tag=M:      Yip et al. 1987 give the Acc-Nom example Mig sækir syfja ("me(A) gets sleep(N)",
line=867 tag=M:  meaning `I am getting sleepy'). It has, however, an unclear and a questionable status.
line=868 tag=M:    17
line=869 tag=M:      Gen-Nom is found in certain predicative constructions (e.g. Hans er bráðum von, "his(G) is
line=870 tag=M:  soon expectation(N)", meaning `He is expected to arrive soon').
line=871 tag=B:
line=872 tag=B:
line=873 tag=B:
line=874 tag=B:
line=875 tag=M:                                                 21
line=876 tag=B:
line=877 tag=T:                   `She found the boys boring.'

doc_id=4079 igt_id=igt4079-9 152 169 L+EX B B M M M M M M M M M B B M B G T
language: Icelandic (isl)
line=152 tag=L+EX:  (7)      a.       Hana      þyrstir.                                     Monadic verb
line=153 tag=B:
line=154 tag=B:
line=155 tag=M:  3
line=156 tag=M:    See for instance Sigurðsson 1989 (p. 198 ff.), Jónsson 1997-1998 and Jónsson 1998. Jónsson 1998
line=157 tag=M:  contains a list of around 690 non-passive predicates that take a non-nominative subject, but many of
line=158 tag=M:  them are `complex' in the sense that they enter into more than one quirky construction (i.e. the number
line=159 tag=M:  of quirky constructions is considerably higher). In addition, many passives take a non-nominative
line=160 tag=M:  subject. Importantly, also, certain quirky constructions are productive and thus cannot really be listed.
line=161 tag=M:  4
line=162 tag=M:    Mediopassives or `middles' in -st are for instance not treated as a special predicate type, a disputable
line=163 tag=M:  simplification.
line=164 tag=B:
line=165 tag=B:
line=166 tag=M:                                                      2
line=167 tag=B:
line=168 tag=G:                 her.ACC thirsts
line=169 tag=T:                 `She is thirsty.'

line=844 tag=B:
line=845 tag=B:
line=846 tag=M:  17
line=847 tag=M:     In lack of a better term. For our limited purposes, the nature of the position in question, as well as the label
line=848 tag=M:  assigned to it, is immaterial. What matters here is only the simple fact that the order Noun-Genitive is derived by
line=849 tag=M:  raising of the noun to a position, P, to the left of the genitive. For ease of exposition, I refer to P as `Spec/G'.
line=850 tag=M:  However, in minimal feature syntax as developed in Sigurðsson 2004a, 2004b, X-bar theoretic notions like
line=851 tag=M:  `head' and `specifier' are meaningless.
